Award.AbstractNarration:
Differential geometry is a branch of mathematics that studies the shapes of geometric objects, called manifolds. Differential geometry is the key mathematics in Einstein's theory of relativity, being used to describe the curvature of space-time in the presence of a body of mass and energy. As such, understanding the geometry and topology of manifolds is a fundamental problem in science. This project will focus on studying the behavior of evolution equations on manifolds. Geometric flows have proved to be very important in mathematics, in particular, Ricci flow has been very popular for its use in the resolution of some central problems, such as the long standing Poincare conjecture. Geometric flows can be used to study a fundamental question of geometry, which is to find canonical metrics on a given manifold. The Ricci flow proposes to do this in an analytic way, by flowing a given metric in time towards an improved, canonical one. This proposal will investigate the formation of singularities along the flow and will attempt to understand them in dimension four. There are possible applications of this study to theoretical physics, because Ricci flow can be seen as the renormalization group flow in string theory. Other related flows, like mean curvature flow, have further remarkable applications to other fields, such as in computer visualization, for eliminating noise, or in metallurgy, for heat treatment of metals. The outreach components of this project disseminate the results to general public and contribute to developing of young talent.

Ricci flow was introduced by Hamilton in the early eighties, in a fundamental work devoted to understanding positively curved three dimensional manifolds. It became clear later that if one flows an arbitrary metric on a given manifold, the flow will generally develop singularities. One needs to understand these singularities in order to continue the flow, and to not loose any significant topological information about the space. The singularities of Ricci flow are modeled by Ricci solitons, which are fixed points of the flow, modulo diffeomorphisms and scalings. Perelman classified three dimensional shrinking Ricci solitons, and used this classification in the resolution of the Poincare conjecture. This has attracted much attention on the higher dimensional problem, and its applications. The goal of this project is to understand the structure and properties of Ricci solitons, in arbitrary dimension. This will lead to a better understanding of how large the space of Ricci solitons is. The study will focus in particular on complete four dimensional shrinking Ricci solitons. There are significant new challenges to this problem, in particular, there exist higher dimensional examples of Ricci solitons which are not positively curved. This principal investigator will attempt to understand the asymptotic geometry of complete four dimensional shrinking Ricci solitons, which is key information for their ultimate classification.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ricci flow is a parabolic differential equation of great importance in geometry. It starts with a given metric on a manifold and flows it in time, thus producing a family of metrics that often improve the original one. Some of its impressive achievements include the resolution of the Poincare conjecture, and the differentiable sphere theorem. But being a nonlinear process, the flow usually develops singularities, and so it cannot be continued after some finite time. The main objective of this proposal was to study and understand the structure of these singularities. Many of the singularities formed under Ricci flow are modeled by shrinking Ricci solitons, these are self similar solutions of the flow that generalize Einstein manifolds.  Shrinking solitons are classified in dimensions two and three, which played an important role in the resolution of the Poincare conjecture for three dimensional manifolds. 

Addressing the goal of this proposal, several results have been obtained about arbitrary dimensional shrinking solitons, in joint work of the PI with Jiaping Wang. Most notably, we generalized an important result due to Perelman, that shrinking solitons of positive sectional curvature must be closed manifolds, from dimension three to arbitrary dimension. Moreover, we proved a uniqueness result for the round cylinder as a limit at infinity of a shrinking soliton. 

In dimension four, we formulated a program that would lead to classification of complete noncompact four dimensional shrinking Ricci solitons. Part of this program, about the asymptotic structure at infinity of shrinking solitons, has been verified in our joint work with Jiaping Wang. It is hoped that this progress will advance our understanding of the topology of four dimensional manifolds through the use of Ricci flow. 

The PI has diseminated these results at various domestic and international conferences and has given mini-courses on the topic of Ricci flow and Ricci solitons. A postdoctoral researcher at University of Connecticut, Lihan Wang, has worked with the PI on several questions of this proposal, with promising results. 

The PI is also very involved in spoting and fostering young talent at his home institution. He has been training students for mathematics competitions, such as the Putnam competition and the Calculus competition at University of Connecticut.
